properties.title: Package Naming Conventions in the Apache Harmony Classlib
properties.author: Harmony Documentation Team

section.name: Package Naming Conventions Used in the Apache Harmony Class Library

small.em: This section is inspired by, and derived from, the Eclipse package naming convention documentation.

section.p: The Harmony class library code is organized into Java packages comprising the public API (packages such as java.lang, org.omg.CORBA and so on) and internal implementation packages that all begin org.apache.harmony.

The public APIs are defined by the JSE specification, and as such as managed beyond the direct control of the Apache Harmony project. The other packages are managed by the project development team, and as such the project attributes the following meaning to package names.

subsection.name: All Packages Belong to a Specific Module
subsection.p: Each Java package is owned by a specific module of the Harmony class library. The module name immediately follows the org.apache.harmony prefix.

subsection.name: Package Names within a Module
subsection.p: Modules are free to use whatever package names they choose with the prefix org.apache.harmony.<modulename> .
The following package name segements are reserved to indicate the meanings defined below:

li.p: Packages with this prefix are implementation packages for use within the given module. Types and fields that are visible within these packages MUST NOT be used outside the module itself. Some runtime environments may enforce this reduced visibility scope.

Packages with this prefix contain test code that is not part of the module API or implementation. Some builds may not include these packages. See Testing conventions in the Apache Harmony Classlib for details.
Packages with this prefix contain example code that is not part of the module API or implementation. Some builds may not include these packages.
All other packages within a module contain internal APIs that may be referenced from any module.

subsection.p:
In practice, this means that module developers are free to change the code within an internal package without expecting any consequences beyond the module itself. However, module developers who modify code that is not in an internal package must do so in a manner that ensures
Java binary compatibility .
